text:

Hey guys.

It’s been a while since the last video and
a lot of stuff has been going on, and so today

we’ll be going through some of the biggest
news stories happening in the world of video
game regional differences.

First up, one of the biggest pieces of news
recently has been the announcement that Tokyo

Mirage Sessions will be getting ported to
the Nintendo Switch early next year, in a

new updated version that boasts the addition
of quite a lot of new content.

New features include new story content, dungeons,
playable characters, costumes and songs, and

is slated for a worldwide release January
17th.

The game was originally released in Japan
in 2015 and then the West in 2016 and is notable

due to the game having quite a few differences
between the English and Japanese versions.

Commenting on these localization differences
prior to the game’s release, publishers

Nintendo explained that any changes made to
in-game content were due to “varying requirements

and regulations in the many different territories
Nintendo distributes its products.”

No further details on what these “varying
requirements and regulations” are have been

given, which led to confusion from some fans
over why the game faced these changes.

The new release has brought into question
whether any of these alterations will be reverted

at all and whether any similar changes will
be made to the game’s new content.

It’s also being speculated how the Japanese
release will be handling the game’s content

and especially with a listing over on the
Nintendo website, stating that the Japanese
version will contain English language support.

Whilst for now, these details aren’t known,
this is something that the channel will be

sure to keep an eye on as we approach the
game’s release date.

One point that was noticed during the initial
announcement trailer was that one of the game’s

bosses still had the same changes made to
her appearance that were made in the original

English version – this being the addition
of a thick smoke that stays clinged to the
chest area, keeping it hidden from view.

However, curiously, this same change can also
be found in the Japanese version of the Nintendo
Switch trailer.

There could be a number of reasons for this
though and it doesn’t necessarily mean that

this change will also be made in Japan this
time around.

Also, over on the Japanese official website,
there is currently a screenshot showing Tsubasa

in one of her Japanese outfits and not the
English replacement.

This outfit was changed overseas so that she
is no longer wearing a bikini top but instead
something more modest.

Again, when there’s more details on all
of this, the channel will be sure to report
back with further info.

Next up we have some news on the recently
released The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening
for Nintendo Switch.

The game is a fully fledged remake of the
Game Boy’s Link’s Awakening and the original

had a few localization differences between
the English and Japanese versions, due to

the rules that Nintendo of America had back
in the 90s to ensure that their games were
kept very family friendly.

This saw changes made to the mermaid side
quest, where in the English versions the mermaid
tasks you with finding her lost pearl necklace.

Instead, in the Japanese version, this was
finding her lost bra, which led to a number

of differences between versions to dialogue
and then the necklace and bra items themselves.

In the remake however, the Japanese version
now has the mermaid losing her necklace too

– meaning there are no longer any differences
between the 2 versions.

There was also originally a change made to
the hippo modelling for a painting – who

had breast-like mounds and is half covered
with a towel in the Japanese version.

In the new remake, this is again the same
worldwide – with the Hippo in both versions
now wearing clothes.

Another Nintendo game that’s generated some
attention recently is Fire Emblem: Three Houses

– a game that’s been out for 2 months
now, but has had a post release update that

adds a few new additions to the game, including
a new extra hard difficulty mode.

Alongside this, fans have noticed that a more
subtle change has been made to one of the

game’s support conversations in the English
versions.

In the new update, Bernadetta has a line of
dialogue changed when talking about how her
father treated her when she was younger.

Originally she said: “To train me to be
a good, submissive wife, he’d do things

like tie me to a chair and leave me there
all day, challenging me to stay quiet.”

Whilst now she says: “To train me to be
a good wife, he’d do things like tie me
to a chair.”

This is quite a strange situation as the game
was already out for some time and there seems

to have been no noticeable complaints over
the original line.

As far as being different from the Japanese
original however, looking into the Japanese

version shows that the new English line is
actually perhaps a little more faithful, as

the Japanese version never mentioned being
“submissive” or “challenging to stay
quiet”.

The Japanese version did however say shirokujichū
(四六時中) which could be translated to

English as “day and night” or “around
the clock”, like the original English line’s
use of “all day”.

But, to summarise, the original English line
seems to have been drummed up a little bit

during the translation and the new line is
fairly accurate to the Japanese version but
not perfect.

It is, again, very unusual however for a single
of dialogue to be altered like this post release
and so the situation is of course quite noteworthy.

That’s all for this time though and, once
again, a big thanks to our sponsors at NordVPN.

There will be a link in the description if
you want to go check their big discount out
and, until next time, thank you for watching.
